abstract.text: A simultaneous electroweak and QCD fit of electroweak parameters and parton distribution functions to HERA data on deep inelastic scattering is presented.
The input data are neutral current and charged current inclusive cross sections measured by the H1 and ZEUS collaborations at the ep collider HERA.
The polarization of the electron beam was taken into account for the ZEUS and H1 data recorded between 2004 and 2007.
Results are presented on the vector and axial-vector couplings of the Z boson to uand d-type quarks.
The values are in agreement with Standard Model predictions.
The results on a u and v u represent the most precise measurements from a single process.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION

Data on deep inelastic electron 1 -proton, ep, scattering (DIS) have been used in analyses within the framework of quantum chromo dynamics (QCD) for many years [1] and have formed the basis of investigations of the structure of the proton.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The data from the ep collider HERA extended the reach in the four-momentum-transfer squared, Q 2 , and in Bjorken x, x Bj , by several orders of magnitude with respect to previous fixed-target experiments [2].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: At HERA, values of Q 2 of up to 50 000 GeV 2 were reached, a regime where the contribution of Z exchange becomes comparable to the contribution from photon exchange.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: During the HERA II running period, the HERA collider provided a significant amount of data with beams longitudinally polarized to an average level between 25% and 35%.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This facilitates detailed studies of electroweak (EW) effects.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Recently, the ZEUS collaboration published a combined QCD and electroweak analysis [3] exploiting the ZEUS neutral current (NC) and charged current (CC) e þ p and e − p inclusive cross sections for polarized beams [4][5][6][7].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: For the analysis presented here, cross sections published by the H1 collaboration [8] for polarized beams were also considered.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A combined QCD and EW fit to the H1 and ZEUS data was performed in which PDF parameters and EW parameters, specifically the couplings of the Z boson to uand d-type quarks, were varied simultaneously, such that correlations between PDF and electroweak parameters were properly treated.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In the present paper, the use of H1 and ZEUS polarized data is expected to improve the precision of the vector couplings of the Z boson as detailed in Sec.

body_text.text: II.
QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS
The analysis presented here follows closely the method described in detail in the ZEUS publication [3].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: It uses the next-to-leading-order (NLO) DGLAP [9][10][11][12][13] formalism to describe the evolution of the parton distribution functions (PDFs) with Q 2 and the on-shell definition of
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where sin 2 θ W is the electroweak mixing angle and M W and M Z are the mass of the W and Z boson, respectively.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The EW part of the analysis was performed at leading order with partial higher-order corrections in the on-shell scheme as calculated by EPRC [14].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The RT variable-number heavy-flavor scheme [15][16][17] was employed and the values of PDG14 [18] were used for all masses and couplings throughout the analysis, unless they were free parameters in a fit.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Following the ZEUS QCD and EW analysis [3], the PDFs of the proton were parametrized with 13 free parameters as
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: xŪðxÞ
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: xDðxÞ
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where x is the fraction of the proton momentum carried by the quark.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The normalization parameters, A u v ; A d v ; A g , are constrained by the quark-number sum rules and the momentum sum rule.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The strange-quark distribution is expressed as an x-independent fraction, f s , of the d-type sea, xs ¼ 0.4xD at the starting scale μ 2 f 0 ¼ 1.9 GeV 2 .
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The parameter C 0 g is fixed to C 0 g ¼ 25 [19].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The PDF parameters and the axial-vector and vector couplings of the Z boson to the uand d-type quarks, a u , a d , v u and v d , were fitted to the HERA inclusive crosssection data.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: For this fit, called HH-EW-Z, the ZEUSfitter package 2 was used.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The results were cross-checked with the HERAFitter [20] package.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: In the HH-EW-Z fit, the CC data add to determination of the PDF parameters whereas the NC data serve to determine both the PDF parameters and the EW couplings.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The NC data were published as reduced cross sections which were defined for e − p and e þ p scattering in terms of the generalized structure functionsF 2 ; xF 3 ; F L , as
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where x Bj is the Bjorken scaling variable and y ¼ P • q=P • k is the fraction of the electron energy transferred to the proton in the rest frame of the proton.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: At HERA energies, the mass of the incoming electrons (protons) with energies E e (E p ) can be neglected and the variables Q 2 , x Bj and y are related as Q 2 ¼ sx Bj y, where s ¼ 4E e E p is the square of the electron-proton center-of-mass energy.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The generalized structure functions depend on the longitudinal polarization of the electron beam, which is defined as
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where N R and N L are the numbers of right-and left-handed electrons in the beam.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: It is useful to split the contributions to the structure functions into unpolarized and polarized pieces,F 2 ¼F 2 0 þ P eF2 P and xF 3 ¼ xF 3 0 þ P e xF 3 P , where, at leading order in QCD, 3 the unpolarized pieces are given bỹ
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where the sum runs over uand d-type quarks and
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The polarized pieces are given bỹ
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The variable χ Z denotes the relative strength of Z exchange with respect to photon exchange
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: where ΔR accounts for radiative corrections as implemented in EPRC [14].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The structure function F L is only important at high y, which is not kinematically accessible for the high-Q 2 values at which polarization becomes important and thus is not further discussed.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The structure functionsF 2 and xF 3 described above depend on the vector and axial-vector couplings of the Z boson to the electron ðv e ; a e Þ and to the uand d-type
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: For the HH-EW-Z fit, the couplings a u , v u , a d , v d were free parameters independent of SM predictions.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Given that for the HERA data χ z ≫ χ 2 z , and that v e ≈ 0.04 is very small, it is clear from Eqs.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: (10), (11), (14), (15), that the terms involving the a i couplings are dominant for the unpolarized data, whereas the v i couplings are dominant for the polarized data.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Thus the polarized H1 data should improve the determination of the couplings v u and v d in comparison to the analysis using only ZEUS polarized data [3].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The data used for the HH-EW-Z fit are the data sets for unpolarized beams originally published by H1 [21][22][23][24][25][26][27] and ZEUS [28][29][30][31][32][33][34][35] and the polarized data sets from H1 [8] and ZEUS [4][5][6][7].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: These data are those used as input to the data combination presented by the H1 and ZEUS collaborations [36].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The data sets with different polarization were added and the resulting cross sections were corrected to zero polarization before they were used as input to the H1 and ZEUS data combination.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: A combination of the H1 and ZEUS polarized data preserving the information on polarization has not been published and therefore this analysis reverts to the original sets of cross sections for polarized beams as published by the individual collaborations, except that the ZEUS cross sections for polarized beams [4][5][6][7] are used with updated values of the polarization as published in the ZEUS EW analysis [3].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The reduced cross sections used as input to the analysis were published by the individual collaborations after QED corrections were applied.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: These corrections are mostly on the percent level, but reach 15% for a few cross sections.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The correction factors were calculated by producing Monte Carlo data sets for which radiative corrections were either turned on or off for comparison.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: This was done with the program HERACLES [37], interfaced to the hadronization routines within the program DJANGOH [38].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The H1 collaboration published [8] a cross-check with the programs HECTOR [39] and EPRC [14] and concluded that the uncertainties are below 2% over the complete phase space.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The H1 collaboration included these uncertainties in the uncorrelated uncertainties of their published cross sections, whereas the ZEUS collaboration did not assign any uncertainties to their QED corrections in their original TABLE II.

body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: In addition, results of fits with the PDFs fixed to HH-13p and HERAPDF2.0, for which only the couplings of the Z were free parameters, are given.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Also listed are the SM predictions.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: and the measurements from LEP þ SLC [40], the Tevatron [41,42] and HERA I (H1) [43].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The fits HH-EW-Z and ZEUS-EW-Z are based both on HERA I and HERA II data and were not included in the combinations for PDG14 [18].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The PDG values and all measurements are compared in Fig. 7.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The HH-EW-Z results on the axial-vector and vector couplings to u-type quarks are the most precise results published from a single process.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: As expected, the vector couplings from HH-EW-Z are significantly more accurate than from ZEUS-EW-Z.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The ZEUS collaboration also presented [3] measurements of the electroweak mixing angle and M W .
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: These EW parameters were determined using both NC and CC cross sections.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The factor χ Z , which depends on sin 2 θ W , affects the contributions to the NC cross sections for both polarized and unpolarized beams.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: The dependence of the CC cross sections on sin 2 θ W and M W is described through the factor
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: 1−ΔR and polarization enters through the multiplicative factors ð1 AE P e Þ for e AE scattering, respectively.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Thus, the information contained in the CC cross sections is also not uniquely dependent on polarization.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Therefore, fits including the H1 polarized data produce no significant improvement in the accuracy of the mixing angle and M W compared to the ZEUS-EW analysis [3].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Two fits were performed as cross-checks with the 13 PDF parameters fixed to those of HH-13p and either sin 2  A simultaneous fit to the 13 PDF parameters and both sin 2 θ W and M W also yielded results compatible with the results presented by ZEUS [3].
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: Since the sensitivity with respect to the ZEUS EW fits was not significantly improved, the detailed studies on sin 2 θ W and M W presented in the ZEUS paper were not repeated.
body_text.section: II. QCD AND EW COMBINED ANALYSIS

body_text.text: IV.
SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
The results of a combined electroweak and QCD fit to all available HERA inclusive DIS cross sections, taking into account beam polarization for both the H1 and ZEUS data, have been presented.
body_text.section: IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The results on the couplings of the Z boson to u- These results are compatible with the Standard Model.
body_text.section: IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The exploitation of all available data for polarized beams provides very accurate determinations of the Z-boson couplings.
body_text.section: IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The couplings to the u-type quarks are the most precise values published for a single process.
body_text.section: IV. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

III.
THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

The PDFs of the HH-EW-Z fit are shown in Fig. 1 with experimental/fit, model and parameterization uncertainties, determined as in the ZEUS-EW-Z fit [3] according to the prescriptions of the HERAPDF2.0 analysis [36].
body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

body_text.text: A 13parameter QCD-only fit with the Z couplings fixed to the SM values, called HH-13p, was performed as a reference; the central values for the PDFs of this fit are also shown in Fig. 1 (top).
body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

body_text.text: The PDFs are very similar.

body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

body_text.text: These figures demonstrate very clearly that the HERA data constrain the couplings of the Z boson to the u quark significantly better than the couplings to the d quark.
body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

body_text.text: This is due to the larger u valence content of the proton and the larger charge of the u quark.
body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS

body_text.text: The couplings as determined by HH-EW-Z are compatible with the SM.

body_text.text: Figure 6 shows the 68% C.L. contours from HH-EW-Z, together with the contours from ZEUS-EW-Z [3]
body_text.section: III. THE HH-EW-Z FIT AND THE Z COUPLINGS
